articles.title: Dialogue is ‘not naïve – it’s necessary’ as global divisions deepen, UN Riyadh forum hears
articles.summary: The 11th Global Forum of the UN Alliance of Civilizations opened in Riyadh on Sunday with a blunt message for a world riven by distrust: dialogue is not a luxury – it’s a survival strategy.
articles.content:
The 11th Global Forum opened in Riyadh on Sunday with a blunt message for a world riven by distrust: dialogue is not a luxury – it’s a survival strategy.

Over the next two days, participants gathered in the Saudi capital are expected to insist that cooperation across cultures, religions, and communities remains the only viable way to navigate an era marked by rising polarization and conflict.

Speaking at the opening session, UN Secretary‑General António Guterres pushed back against the notion that the Alliance’s mission is unrealistic or, as critics suggest, “too soft for our hard world.”

Those who dismiss dialogue as naïve, he warned, are mistaken. Diplomacy and cooperation, he said, are not optional, they are essential.

Tweet URL

Two decades have passed since then‑Secretary‑General Kofi Annan launched the initiative in 2005 with support from Spain and Türkiye. The geopolitical landscape has shifted dramatically since, yet the Alliance’s core purpose remains constant: countering extremism and intolerance and helping societies of different cultures and faiths live together in dignity.

The UN chief described the paradox of an age in which humanity is “more connected, yet never more fragmented,” and outlined two divergent futures: one defined by fear, walls, and escalating wars; and another built on bridges between cultures.

Only the second path, he stressed, leads to sustainable peace: “No more 7th of Octobers. No more Gazas destroyed. No more El‑Fashers starved. No more communities massacred, expelled, or scapegoated.”

The Secretary-General pointed to three forces capable of driving positive global change: young people, women and girls, and people of faith. He urged delegates to advance the Alliance’s mission “with courage, clarity, and hope.”

Riyadh Communiqué: a call for coexistence

Countries participating in the Forum endorsed the Riyadh Communiqué, which calls for combating all forms of religious intolerance as a global priority.

The document underscores the central role of education in fostering dialogue, human rights, and peaceful societies, and reaffirms the Alliance’s founding aim: strengthening cooperation among cultures and religions while promoting respect, mutual understanding, and inclusion.

Equal voices, shared responsibility

UNAOC High Representative Miguel Moratinos, who also serves as the UN Special Envoy to Combat Islamophobia, opened the session by stressing that every culture must have an equal voice in shaping the world’s future.

No single perspective should dominate, he said; instead, a truly peaceful and inclusive global community must draw on the wisdom and values of all civilizations.

Mr. Moratinos warned of “the return of hatred,” urging vigilance against growing discrimination. Quoting a verse from the Qur’an’s Surat Al‑Hujurat, he emphasized that human diversity is a source of strength, not division.

He underscored that Islam is a religion of peace and reiterated that Islamophobia must have no place anywhere. At the same time, he insisted that antisemitism must be eradicated, adding: “Legitimate criticism of governments should not be perceived as antisemitic nor as a motive to demonize entire communities.”

Saudi Arabia’s message: Lean into dialogue, don’t retreat

Saudi Arabia’s Foreign Minister, Prince Faisal bin Farhan Al Saud, reaffirmed the Kingdom’s “longstanding commitment to intercultural dialogue.” He said Saudi support for the Alliance reflects a firm belief that engagement among cultures and civilizations is essential to peace, cooperation, and conflict prevention.

He highlighted several Saudi initiatives aimed at promoting dialogue and countering extremism and warned of the increasing spread of religiously and nationally motivated extremist movements, as well as a worrying rise in hate speech and Islamophobia over the past two decades.

Rather than prompting disengagement, he said, these challenges must push nations to reinforce – not abandon – the values of dialogue, communication, and coexistence.

Representatives from Spain and Türkiye, the Alliance’s original co‑sponsors, also spoke, reaffirming the enduring importance of inclusion, mutual respect, and sustained dialogue.

Deepfakes, hate speech, and the push for regulation

The opening day of the Forum also turned its attention to one of the fastest‑moving challenges shaping today’s information landscape: AI‑driven misinformation.

Speakers warned that deepfakes, algorithm‑amplified hate speech, and unregulated systems are already reshaping public debate – and not for the better.

Ismail Serageldin, co‑chair of the Nizami Ganjavi International Center and former Vice President of the World Bank Group, said the use of artificial intelligence is now unavoidable.

He urged the public not to fear new technologies, likening the current moment to the invention of the calculator, when many predicted the end of accounting jobs.

“Instead,” he noted, “they adapted,” and he argued society will do the same today. With the right safeguards, he added, AI could even help people achieve a better work‑life balance.

Mr. Serageldin went on to underscore that AI will not replace humans, but people who understand how to use it will gain a decisive advantage. Smart regulations must protect the public without smothering innovation or creativity, he explained.

Achraf Tasfaout, a data scientist working in the banking sector, warned that AI is accelerating the spread of hate speech and making it harder for people to tell real content from deepfakes.

He called for clear rules that set boundaries for safe use while still enabling new ideas to flourish. Policymakers and journalists, he said, have a crucial role to play in defending society. Moreover, young people, as the most active users of AI, will be central to creating the solutions. He added that AI itself can be harnessed to counter many of the problems it creates.

Atif Rashid, Editor‑in‑Chief of Analyst News, cautioned that AI systems are being released “too quickly,” often without essential safety measures. He said it can feel as if “humans are guinea pigs” in a global experiment, with regulation arriving only after widespread public exposure.

Mr. Rashid pointed to examples where AI has encouraged harmful behavior, which he described as ‘AI psychosis’, and stressed that new systems must be designed to serve all of humanity, grounded firmly in human values.

articles.personality_title: UN forum in Riyadh stresses dialogue as key to peace amid global divisions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The world today faces growing divisions, conflicts, and distrust between different cultures and religions. To address these challenges, the United Nations Alliance of Civilizations (UNAOC), started in 2005, works to promote understanding and peaceful coexistence among diverse communities.

**What happened** – The 11th Global Forum of the UNAOC opened in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, with leaders, experts, and diplomats gathering to discuss how dialogue and cooperation can help reduce extremism and intolerance. UN Secretary-General António Guterres emphasized that talking and working together are not signs of weakness but necessary for survival. Countries attending agreed on the Riyadh Communiqué, which calls for fighting religious intolerance and highlights education as a tool to build respect and inclusion.

**Impact** – This forum is important because it brings together many nations to agree on common goals for peace and cooperation at a time when hatred and divisions are rising. It also addresses modern challenges like AI-driven misinformation and hate speech, calling for smart rules to keep technology safe and helpful. The focus on young people, women, and faith groups shows a clear plan to involve those who can drive positive change.

**What's next step** – The ideas and agreements from the Riyadh Forum will guide future efforts by the UN and countries to promote dialogue and fight extremism. Experts and governments will work on regulating new technologies like artificial intelligence to prevent misuse, while also encouraging education and respect among cultures.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN’s Global Forum in Riyadh highlights dialogue and cooperation as essential tools to overcome global divisions and build a more peaceful world.

articles.personality_title_es: El foro de la ONU en Riad destaca el diálogo como clave para la paz en medio de divisiones globales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hoy en día, el mundo enfrenta crecientes divisiones, conflictos y desconfianza entre diferentes culturas y religiones. Para abordar estos retos, la Alianza de Civilizaciones de las Naciones Unidas (UNAOC), creada en 2005, trabaja para promover la comprensión y la convivencia pacífica entre diversas comunidades.

**Impacto** – Este foro es importante porque reúne a muchas naciones para acordar objetivos comunes de paz y cooperación en un momento en que el odio y las divisiones están creciendo. También aborda desafíos modernos como la desinformación y el discurso de odio impulsados por la inteligencia artificial, pidiendo reglas inteligentes para mantener la tecnología segura y útil. El enfoque en jóvenes, mujeres y grupos de fe muestra un plan claro para involucrar a quienes pueden impulsar cambios positivos.

**Próximo paso** – Las ideas y acuerdos del Foro de Riad guiarán los esfuerzos futuros de la ONU y los países para promover el diálogo y combatir el extremismo. Expertos y gobiernos trabajarán en regular nuevas tecnologías como la inteligencia artificial para evitar abusos, mientras fomentan la educación y el respeto entre culturas.

articles.title: UN marks first World Turkic Language Family Day
articles.summary: The UN cultural agency, UNESCO, is preparing to celebrate the first ever World Turkic Language Family Day on Monday, following a decision by UNESCO’s General Conference in Samarkand to establish 15 December as an annual observance.
articles.content:
The new commemoration highlights the shared linguistic and cultural heritage of Turkic-speaking peoples and reinforces UNESCO’s wider commitment to multilingualism and cultural diversity.

A historic date

The choice of 15 December is rooted in a landmark moment in linguistic scholarship. On that day in 1893, Danish linguist Vilhelm Thomsen announced he had deciphered the alphabet of the Orkhon Inscriptions – some of the oldest known written records of the Turkic language family.

His breakthrough opened the door to a deeper understanding of a linguistic tradition that today connects dozens of communities across Eurasia.

A global language family

Turkic languages – including Azerbaijani, Kazakh, Kyrgyz, Turkish, Turkmen and Uzbek – are spoken natively by more than 200 million people across an area stretching roughly 12 million square kilometres.

UNESCO notes that these languages carry a rich written heritage, strong oral traditions and diverse cultural practices shared across many Member States.

The proclamation of the new Day followed a joint request from Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Türkiye and Uzbekistan and was supported by 21 Member States, reflecting broad recognition of the value of linguistic diversity.

Strengthening cooperation

UNESCO says the annual observance aligns with the UN’s wider multilingualism agenda, set out in General Assembly resolution 71/328.

By dedicating a day to the Turkic language family, the agency aims to encourage linguistic cooperation, cultural exchange and dialogue among civilizations.

Planned activities include awareness-raising initiatives, academic research and programmes to safeguard Turkic languages and oral traditions.

Annual celebration

The day will be marked with exhibitions, lectures, literary events and artistic performances designed to showcase the historical depth and contemporary vitality of Turkic languages.

UNESCO says the commemoration is an opportunity to honour linguistic diversity as part of humanity’s common heritage and to strengthen international efforts to protect languages as essential vehicles of identity, knowledge and cultural expression.

articles.personality_title: UN inaugurates World Turkic Language Family Day to celebrate cultural heritage
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations cultural agency, UNESCO, has decided to create a new annual day to celebrate the Turkic language family. This family includes many languages spoken by over 200 million people across a large part of Eurasia. 

**What happened** – On December 15, UNESCO will mark the first World Turkic Language Family Day. This date was chosen because, on December 15, 1893, a Danish linguist named Vilhelm Thomsen decoded the Orkhon Inscriptions, some of the oldest written Turkic records. The decision was made during a UNESCO meeting in Samarkand and supported by several countries where Turkic languages are spoken.

**Impact** – This new day highlights the shared history, culture, and languages of Turkic-speaking peoples. It also supports UNESCO’s goal to promote many languages and cultural diversity worldwide. The celebration will help protect these languages and encourage people to learn about and respect them.

**What's next step** – Each year, the day will include events like exhibitions, talks, and performances to show the importance and beauty of Turkic languages. UNESCO plans to use this day to promote cooperation between countries and support research and programs that protect Turkic languages and traditions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – UNESCO has created a special day to honor the Turkic language family, promoting cultural understanding and language preservation for millions of people.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’ONU inaugure la Journée mondiale de la famille des langues turciques pour célébrer le patrimoine culturel
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’agence culturelle de l’ONU, l’UNESCO, a décidé de créer une nouvelle journée annuelle pour célébrer la famille des langues turciques. Cette famille comprend de nombreuses langues parlées par plus de 200 millions de personnes dans une grande partie de l’Eurasie.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 15 décembre, l’UNESCO célébrera la première Journée mondiale de la famille des langues turciques. Cette date a été choisie car, le 15 décembre 1893, un linguiste danois nommé Vilhelm Thomsen a déchiffré les inscriptions d’Orkhon, parmi les plus anciens écrits turciques connus. La décision a été prise lors d’une réunion de l’UNESCO à Samarcande et soutenue par plusieurs pays où l’on parle ces langues.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle journée met en lumière l’histoire, la culture et les langues partagées par les peuples turciques. Elle soutient aussi l’objectif de l’UNESCO de promouvoir la diversité des langues et des cultures dans le monde. Cette célébration aidera à protéger ces langues et à encourager leur connaissance et leur respect.

**Prochaines étapes** – Chaque année, cette journée comprendra des événements comme des expositions, des conférences et des spectacles pour montrer l’importance et la richesse des langues turciques. L’UNESCO souhaite utiliser cette journée pour encourager la coopération entre pays et soutenir la recherche et les programmes de protection des langues et traditions turciques.

**Message clé en une phrase** – L’UNESCO a créé une journée spéciale pour honorer la famille des langues turciques, favorisant la compréhension culturelle et la préservation des langues pour des millions de personnes.
articles.personality_title_es: ONU inaugura el Día Mundial de la Familia de Lenguas Túrquicas para celebrar el patrimonio cultural
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La agencia cultural de la ONU, la UNESCO, decidió crear un nuevo día anual para celebrar la familia de lenguas túrquicas. Esta familia incluye muchos idiomas hablados por más de 200 millones de personas en gran parte de Eurasia.

**Qué pasó** – El 15 de diciembre, la UNESCO celebrará el primer Día Mundial de la Familia de Lenguas Túrquicas. Esta fecha se eligió porque, el 15 de diciembre de 1893, un lingüista danés llamado Vilhelm Thomsen descifró las Inscripciones de Orkhon, algunos de los registros escritos túrquicos más antiguos. La decisión se tomó en una reunión de la UNESCO en Samarcanda y contó con el apoyo de varios países donde se hablan estas lenguas.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo día destaca la historia, cultura y lenguas compartidas por los pueblos túrquicos. También apoya la meta de la UNESCO de promover la diversidad lingüística y cultural en todo el mundo. La celebración ayudará a proteger estos idiomas y a fomentar que las personas los conozcan y respeten.

**Próximo paso** – Cada año, el día incluirá eventos como exposiciones, charlas y presentaciones para mostrar la importancia y riqueza de las lenguas túrquicas. La UNESCO planea usar este día para promover la cooperación entre países y apoyar la investigación y programas que protejan las lenguas y tradiciones túrquicas.

**Mensaje clave en una frase** – La UNESCO ha creado un día especial para honrar la familia de lenguas túrquicas, promoviendo el entendimiento cultural y la preservación de idiomas para millones de personas.
